165565DD1C514EE2B92733483754E3A6.description:
Choose to act in
ways that show
respect for others’
feelings and points of
view most of the time
with guidance and
support (compliment
each other during play,
work out conflicts,
show respect for
opinions expressed by
others).

C24206EC198B4587A54523B9103CD1F7.description:
Show awareness
that their behavior can
affect the feelings of
others (say, “I didn’t
mean to scare you
when I yelled.”).

23D59F79DE404784A5F9FF8E5214ADED.description:
Communicate understanding and empathy
for others’ feelings.

548BA3CFACA247ADA7A14B44B41C0A16.description:
Show awareness
that other people have
different feelings (“I
like raisins but he
doesn’t.” “I’m scared
on that ride but she
isn’t.”).

8DE3CFC5C36549918551E074949C145A.description:
Offer help to meet
the needs of others
(pick up item someone
dropped, help another
child who is having
trouble building a
block tower).

B258D456972644DD9D06739D782304B8.description:
Communicate
concern for others
(share a toy with
someone who doesn’t
have one, ask, “Are
you OK?”).

FF1DD0C2CE464B128F95DA7A36388FC4.description:
Try to comfort
another child or an
adult who is upset
(bring a comfort
object, pat the person
on the back).

09B701E088EA48349E035D6F7A630B5C.description:
Recognize facial
expressions or actions
associated with
different emotions.

24002119664E49E3AAF3B1E596B6CD3E.description:
Offer help to meet the
needs of others (pick
up item someone
dropped, help another
child who is having
trouble building a block
tower).

89BF4A456F43470682ACC8BD7CEA0039.description:
Communicate
concern for others
(share a toy with
someone who doesn’t
have one, ask, “Are
you OK?”).

5848D7770D94499BB4268423D4154221.description:
Try to comfort
another child or an
adult who is upset
(bring a comfort
object, pat the person
on the back).

C381A4C77C2E446CA10F7030EF0E45E8.description:
Match their tone and
emotions to that
of others during
interactions.

F71BB734FFFB40E38EF422C78BE274B2.description:
Look at familiar
caregivers to see
how the caregiver is
feeling (do something
wrong and look to
see if the caregiver
is angry, bump head
and start crying
after the caregiver
expresses concern/
tries to comfort).

94FFF572D64D4021A2CC85F79E344DA0.description:
Try to comfort
another child or an
adult who is upset
(bring a comfort
object, pat the person
on the back).

85B394DAFD0B4997A5B15776AE0B53B6.description:
Respond differently
to positive vs. negative
emotional expressions
of others.

CF80C3F1E3B34CCC9082AF9EB19E2E6A.description:
Become upset when
another infant is
crying.

8E6E83676222446A80089764088A1341.description: Children recognize and respond appropriately to the needs and feelings of others.

F81AB844DE824778A478F736F7A57B9D.description:
Use problem-solving
strategies when feeling
angry or frustrated.

F0DBACA4680B4261A6BFC21751332B21.description:
Give reasons for their
feelings that may include
thoughts and beliefs as
well as outside events (“I’m
happy because I wanted to
win and I did.”).

A304BF2D450E4CA99ABC8B639B9D0261.description:
Use a larger vocabulary
for talking about different
feelings (“I’m frustrated with
that puzzle!” “I’m excited
about our trip.”).

514FDC9E392F408BB7CFDBCA8E8AEC67.description:
Independently manage
and express feelings
effectively most of the time.

2DC3BB3AD7584C5B8D3249D9EBD7DD6A.description:
Express a range of
emotions (happiness,
sadness, fear, anger,
disgust, tenderness,
hostility, shame, guilt,
satisfaction, and love)
with their face, body, vocal
sounds, and words.

2192D72138F842FD8C6DF6BCA112EF49.description:
Describe reasons for
their feelings (“I’m sad
because Grandma’s
leaving.” “That makes
me mad when you do
that!”).

C214825521E74899A8C404E14F2E1F07.description:
Use a variety of
words or signs to
express and manage
feelings more clearly.

CD77AD68F3F942D8AB7ABDF52926D43E.description:
Express a range of
emotions (happiness,
sadness, fear, anger,
disgust, tenderness,
hostility, shame, guilt,
satisfaction, and love)
with their face, body,
vocal sounds, and
words.

4FE811D027AA4A649F40DBD50C265427.description:
Manage emotions
and control impulses
with guidance and
support (Say “I don’t
like that!” instead of
hitting; wait by door
instead of running
ahead when excited
to go out).

413D57494E9C4869A47A317EFBFA5341.description:
Express a range of
emotions (happiness,
sadness, fear, anger,
disgust, tenderness,
hostility, shame, guilt,
satisfaction, and love)
with their face, body,
vocal sounds, and
words.

432BAE9893EE434D8C59AD8EC8D14EDB.description:
Find comfort and
calm down in a
familiar setting or with
a familiar person.

6D2C739CD0214983AA1F6DC0A1199FCF.description:
Separate from
parent or main
caregiver without
being overcome by
stress.

589823F52E354B49ACABC10B531D1D51.description:
Use body language,
facial expression, and
sometimes words to
communicate feelings
(clap when happy,
pout and hunch
shoulders when
sad, shout “Whee!”
when excited).

0A2E34CC44714AE9B87536BFCE1F1BFC.description:
Express a range of emotions (happiness, sadness, fear and anger) with their face,
body, and voice.

9F0EFDFDDA704324B748AB3B25FC677C.description:
Soothe themselves
(suck thumb or
pacifier, shift attention,
snuggle with soft toy).

A39711931583421DB40E7BD19F6BD8D6.description:
Show when they
feel overwhelmed or
are in distress or pain
(cry, yawn, look away,
extend arms or legs,
arch their body, fuss).

82A7D5BAFDBF467096110388E616D87E.description:
Express a range of emotions (happiness, sadness, fear, and anger) with their face,
body, and voice.

97BF17DB32A44F77AE2FC4CB69C09513.description: Children identify, manage, and express their feelings.

A915A8EE23874DA79C2345D9B6CD923F.description:
Express respect and
caring for all people,
including people with
disabilities.

7549E62A437548108D56CED05DB1C385.description:
Use a variety of strategies
to solve problems and
conflicts with increasing
independence.

3490964108C24F7EAB138EE7EC6A23B9.description:
Anticipate consequences
and plan ways to solve
problems effectively, with
guidance and support.

F3CD4EDE7C384BB4A71079C1264282C0.description:
Balance their own needs
with those of others in the
group.

5D1E55752E6B4DD495B3B6098B774F2C.description:
Make requests clearly
and effectively most of the
time.

99DF5012D4934FC9BB560AD6C226F56B.description:
Follow social rules, transitions, and routines that
have been explained to
them.

7C61291FD08641FE8496F78C7A748766.description:
Notice and accept
similarities and differences
among all people, including
people with disabilities.

C773A48EE4894C298D47D3B5B56E2120.description:
Work to resolve conflicts
effectively, with guidance and
support.

A6F13E68B062455D8EC4B3B0EF3CA4B9.description:
Wait for a short time to get
what they want (a turn with a
toy, a snack).

86E034ECFB674FA0965C5CCCE1C00B24.description:
Show awareness that their
actions affect others (move
carefully around classmate’s
block structure).

B86EAFBDF047496E8B817AD0DFFADA6C.description:
Often make requests clearly
and effectively.

300B1B56251C484CA5747BBE6C555B17.description:
Follow social rules,
transitions, and routines that
have been explained to them,
with reminders and practice.

7363F9FE86A14C7CAF46DF7CF3BF01B8.description:
Wait for a short time to get
what they want (a turn with a
toy, snack), with guidance and
support.

E43DC8CE818640B8A46C0547C7B3BE11.description:
Show caring and cooperation
(help to put away toys, offer to
help another person).

AE0206ECA7314A4699BF3F9A68987A55.description:
Evaluate their own and others’
actions as right or wrong
(pointing out another child is
climbing on the table).

7CDD5339886B48029352C8B54560DD57.description:
Adjust their behavior to fit
different situations (tiptoe near
a sleeping baby, use a quiet
voice inside, run outside).

C4C31BF4BE564600929B14ABD921B8D5.description:
Follow social rules,
transitions, and routines
that have been explained to
them, with reminders and
practice.

18306279F8CB4D5FBEB3D95E71BDF2B0.description:
Accept adult help to
resolve problems and
conflicts, and cooperate
when adults redirect
them from a situation that
poses a problem.

EB7D65940CB748469FC831F712BF9443.description:
Control impulses some
of the time (look at
forbidden object and say,
“No, no,” allow adult to
direct them to a different
activity).

E35AB5FC44584ABA813EFB6991599127.description:
Follow simple directions
some of the time.

200CC8D2ED1B4542844162F0B0BE7934.description:
Use gestures, sounds,
objects, or words to get
another person to do
something (bring box to
adult to be opened, make
noise to get someone to
look).

62BD4B5ABB874D03B63596CDB1EE9033.description: Children demonstrate the social and behavioral skills needed to successfully participate in groups.

EEFACC55596749D8B5C720DCEB010DBE.description:
Play and interact
cooperatively with other
children (work on project
together, exchange
ideas).

C90127DA8C6B4691A7A9D7AC57FC10C3.description:
Use language effectively
to have conversations
with other children and
influence another child’s
behavior (negotiate
sharing a toy, plan how
to build a block tower
together).

D9411E095BDE4DE4B467A22A60E701C9.description:
Seek and give support
to children they identify as
friends.

E479C617FEBB44CFAB0CAC51105CF825.description:
Form and maintain
friendships with other
children of diverse cultural
backgrounds and abilities.

47270F5074B145868888B925B2818FB4.description:
Demonstrate social
skills when interacting
with other children (turntaking, conflict resolution,
sharing).

66F2C6BAFFDF495D84A7EECCF0BB1C28.description:
Show ease and
comfort in their
interactions with
familiar children.

9387B441EB02444EB11540286CF13C2E.description:
Approach other
children easily,
expecting positive
interactions.

2E1212079BE243F890FAE333E6115D94.description:
Identify another child
as a friend.

C30D883E1F474B22A304FB47951FAE73.description:
Form and maintain
friendships with a few
other children.

46E53EA86573455A81A1526A4D814F5A.description:
Demonstrate social
skills when interacting
with other children
(turn-taking, conflict
resolution, sharing).

38DD6B50EC3D4B74AA8FCC7ABB1AC0E8.description:
Show positive emotion
and turn-taking with
familiar playmates
(agree to chase each
other, watch and imitate
each other’s play with
toys).

96190C1FDEDE4E5A849570004D5E9A27.description:
Participate in play with
other children.

F515512721C9477FA741D395F80E08B2.description:
Use appropriate
words to influence
playmates’ behavior
(“Play with me.” “Stop
hitting me.”).

795A556BDE924D0CADA692939AE27EA8.description:
Remember and use
names of familiar
playmates.

8DEFFA1CC87E49748A98D6000A56220D.description:
Show affection or
preference for particular
children (spontaneously
hug, want to play, call
child a friend).

8FFAEA4D0B114FA2922DBB8EC04F19BE.description:
Offer toys and
objects to other
children.

3DDD31EF81D544E4BD4E2EE8DEE6A122.description:
Imitate actions of
older siblings and
playmates.

E55171F3D85F4BD88FF74767A073E6E1.description:
Show pleasure at
the arrival of familiar
peers.

37A66615B96B4C1DB5263E5D71DBEF3B.description:
Notice other infants
and children (look at
them, turn in other’s
direction, reach for
them, touch them).

94202F192815422A87A76E1CFA859E49.description: Children form relationships and interact positively with other children.

B5CC7A94D90343DB8506ED81C86EC527.description:
Use language
effectively to continue
conversations with
familiar adults and
to influence their
behavior (ask for help,
ask an adult to do
something).

FBA33509C8C241149A8E77D8712206BA.description:
Form positive
relationships with new
teachers or caregivers
over time.

B971E13242554F19B553FD56576C3F76.description:
Seek out trusted teachers and caregivers as needed
(for emotional support,
physical assistance,
social interaction,
problem solving, and
approval).

2B237F8981054EF6ACAA37BB94D193B5.description:
Show ease and
comfort in their
interactions with
familiar adults.

8B310D6F54AE4585A384913EE3F59D5F.description:
Given time, form
positive relationships
with new teachers or
caregivers.

F7F9B07D12F543A3BEEF06770AAD847B.description:
Show affection for
adults they are close
to.

E47EA563A3994151B10B2C3BCCA2617F.description:
Seek out trusted teachers and caregivers as needed (for emotional support,
physical assistance,
social interaction,
problem solving, and
approval).

F8E479395A3840C78C988DB01DE60974.description:
Use words to influence
caregivers’ behavior
(ask for help, talk about
something they want the
adult to do).

FA69A6F1F44C4640861FFD1DCB814116.description:
Are less likely to get
upset when primary
caregiver is with them.

69C413A18B314F3387B454BF19755CEF.description:
Seek help from trusted
adults when upset (when
fearful or having difficulty
with something).

84C1BFD26B7F4235BC8A0D1C6BF1CA28.description:
Form close relationships
with their primary
caregivers and other
familiar adults.

5F819DF23A784F40A59029023DCAD87F.description:
Seek out trusted teachers and caregivers as needed (for emotional support, physical
assistance, social
interaction, problem
solving, and approval).

9535D6EA92CD40DD98582CA9F816C80B.description:
Look to adult
for affirmation of
behavior/guidance.

C51727D496604AFBAB864A2B7223F964.description:
Offer toys and
objects to familiar
adults.

F0A46E930BE64385BDED5266DA61AE87.description:
Show preference
for and emotional
connection with
adults who take
care of them on a
regular basis (“check
in” with caregiver
while playing, greet
family member with
big hug, seek out
caregiver when upset
or uncertain, exhibit
anxiety when adult
leaves).

B30DBB0BBFD946A3A6EBC8B430AA52DF.description:
Imitate sounds, facial
expressions, or
gestures they see
other people do (peeka-boo, hands up for
“so big”).

022B642EC40B4B4DB8E3768E6E7DDE59.description:
Show signs of
separation anxiety
when a familiar
caregiver leaves.

659BD308B7274113AA39452606352E9D.description:
Seek to be near their
caregivers; stop crying
when they come near.

E319519D3F52408C8DE4E2B2D51601D7.description:
Recognize and reach
out to familiar people.

9CC11B8B442F4BAFA1453B531BC5402B.description:
Enjoy being held,
cuddled, and talked
to by familiar adults.

2A5CD18B162B40A88DA963CD3D1A5FB4.description:
Children form relationships and interact positively with familiar adults who are consistent
and responsive to their needs.

49B72610E80C44BAB3EDE4EA365358CC.description:
Express opinions
about their abilities in
different areas (“I’m a
good friend.” I can run
fast.” “I know all my
letters!”).

C0230A31D7F4488D8A98850AA4CF1BE6.description:
Stick with tasks
even when they are
challenging.

C5316BABD6464A0A9CDCB027105E2447.description: Express the belief that they can do many things.

58B5932498F947108912A86A70D17A70.description: Express positive feelings about themselves by showing and/or telling others about themselves, things they like, or things they have done.

0F7E9D01A12146A2986EB3D23B9D4B6D.description:
Attempt to reach
goals without help
from others (push adult
away, say “Me do it
myself!”).

E5BDDF56A6B74204ADF2FD9F6229E314.description:
Show confidence
in their abilities
through actions and/
or language (try to lift a
heavy object, say, “I’m
strong!”).

FC04A78A6E2240D98BCC2348B86405AB.description:
Explore the environment independently to satisfy their own interests (seek out toy
or favorite materials).

CFEA5462F6B54AA89C10B7DA3168FF13.description: Express positive feelings about themselves by showing and/or themselves, things they like, or things they have done. ESD-2g

97A52EE0550943DCA4B357F550D27C04.description:
Bring others things
they like or show
them things they have
done.

291E8DB84F594A35A9E52145FF70784D.description:
Show confidence in
their ability to make
things happen by
repeating or changing
their actions to reach
a goal (move closer to
reach an object they
want).

38A12CDCEEBB4248AD78726B9138ECBE.description:
Explore the
environment on their
own, but check in
with a familiar, trusted
adult occasionally.

435EF6E65B704504AA49D43B3FAFB290.description:
Explore the
environment with
support from a familiar,
trusted adult.

A19F8FD80F2C422593DBE738EBED6F6C.description:
Show pleasure at
things they have done
(wiggle, coo, laugh).

CF679EDB775044EE922CB3D5335C7624.description:
Show they expect
results from their
actions (repeat loud
noise to gain attention,
hit toy over and over to
produce sound).

98DAB8DD78FF4528B611551017012509.description: Children express positive feelings about themselves and confidence in what they can do.

7153FBF032E64448A29EB70B8963CE70.description:
Choose to spend
more time on preferred
activities, and express
awareness of skills
they are developing.

4E7503F40CC2433090CA16BD84AEB14F.description:
Express awareness
that they are members
of different groups
(e.g., family, preschool
class, ethnic group).

5529DE36008B460CBD56D31682E6175B.description:
Describe themselves
in concrete ways, with
greater detail and
accuracy (“My eyes
are brown.” “I am
tall.”).

8F90D342F6E54B1D995214BD7F37F2DB.description:
Choose activities
they like and name
their favorite activities.

578E1D31274A473488E991EEBEDC1E64.description:
Use own first and
last name.

7ADB86503A0D4C11BBC9E2402D6A5EB5.description:
Express a sense of
belonging to a group
(say “There’s Kirby
from my class,” move
to stand with own
group upon request, “I
am a girl.”).

06A101C57A934B50B849B9100B92D4CC.description:
Describe self
(characteristics
that can be seen,
things they can do,
things they like,
possessions).

D69A43509CAD4369A9511C43DA8E1699.description:
Make choices and
have favorite clothes,
toys, and activities.

043636CAEB1548B8A9EA3FB2031B3D39.description:
Use their own name
or a personal pronoun
to refer to themselves
(I, me, and mine).

F6EB1A84564544F087FAFED4E23A70C3.description:
Show awareness
of some of their own
characteristics and
things they can do
(recognize themselves
in pictures, say, “I help
Daddy!”).

AC4736CB92BF4567B1E54B415B99707C.description:
Express choices
with gestures, signs,
or words (select a toy
they want).

19338F8E60D444978428480D2F4BD475.description:
Recognize
themselves in a mirror
(point to self, make
faces in mirror).

831127A454F34837A054518406B978A1.description:
Show awareness of
specific body parts.

E9AF1FA2AED548818A843FEC93CC897F.description:
Express likes and
dislikes (smile, cry, and
protest).

34F5D60CC3ED44F3B7E21CEC3490676E.description:
Respond to their
name with sounds or
movement.

C7207DADDDB44119BCC3FD07C38B7A62.description:
Show interest in
their image in a mirror
(stare, smile, reach out
to touch).

2390D7DD20644FD0B181AD22AA841072.description:
Show awareness
of their bodies (study
own hands and feet
moving; use hands,
mouth, and eyes in
coordination to explore
their bodies).

4C1E5DB8411F4D1DA3EDA8CB1CBD8713.description: Children demonstrate a positive sense of self-identity and self-awareness.
